title: Definition of a Function
content: A function is a relation in which each input has exactly one output. It can be represented using equations, graphs, or mappings.

title: Domain and Range of a Function
content: The domain is the set of all possible input values, and the range is the set of all corresponding output values of a function.

title: Function Notation
content: Function notation f(x) represents the output of function f for input x. The expression f(a) means the value of the function at a.

title: Vertical Line Test for Functions
content: A graph represents a function if and only if no vertical line intersects the graph at more than one point.

title: Piecewise-defined Function
content: A piecewise-defined function is defined by different expressions over different parts of its domain.

title: Even and Odd Functions
content: A function is even if f(−x) = f(x) for all x in its domain, and odd if f(−x) = −f(x).

title: Increasing, Decreasing, Constant Intervals
content: A function is increasing on intervals where its graph rises, decreasing where it falls, and constant where it is flat.

title: Local and Absolute Extrema
content: A function has a local maximum or minimum at a point if it is the highest or lowest value nearby. An absolute extremum is the highest or lowest value on the entire domain.

title: Function Composition
content: The composition of functions f and g is written as (f ∘ g)(x) = f(g(x)). Evaluate the inner function first.

title: Inverse of a Function
content: The inverse of a function f is a function f⁻¹ such that f(f⁻¹(x)) = x and f⁻¹(f(x)) = x. A function has an inverse only if it is one-to-one.

title: Operations on Functions
content: Functions can be added, subtracted, multiplied, or divided: (f ± g)(x) = f(x) ± g(x), (f·g)(x) = f(x)g(x), (f / g)(x) = f(x)/g(x) where g(x) ≠ 0.

title: Domain of Combined Functions
content: The domain of f ± g or f·g is the intersection of domains of f and g. For f / g, also exclude points where g(x) = 0.

title: Verifying Inverse Functions
content: To verify f and g are inverses, check that f(g(x)) = x and g(f(x)) = x over their domains.

title: Finding Inverse Algebraically
content: To find the inverse of a function f(x), switch x and y in the equation y = f(x), then solve for y.

title: One-to-One Function
content: A function is one-to-one if each output value corresponds to exactly one input value. It passes the horizontal line test.

title: Absolute Value as a Piecewise Function
content: The function f(x) = |x| can be expressed as a piecewise function: f(x) = x if x ≥ 0, and f(x) = −x if x < 0.

title: Greatest Integer (Floor) Function
content: The greatest integer function, denoted ⌊x⌋, gives the greatest integer less than or equal to x. Its graph is a step function.

title: Signum (Sign) Function
content: The sign function sgn(x) returns 1 if x > 0, 0 if x = 0, and −1 if x < 0.

title: Increasing/Decreasing via Derivative-Free Analysis
content: In Precalculus, a function is increasing where its values get larger as x increases, based on table or graph, without formal derivatives.

title: Function Symmetry Types
content: A graph has y-axis symmetry if f(−x) = f(x), origin symmetry if f(−x) = −f(x), and x-axis symmetry if (x, y) and (x, −y) are both on the graph (not a function).

title: Piecewise and Continuity at a Point
content: A function is continuous at x = c if lim x→c⁻ f(x) = lim x→c⁺ f(x) = f(c). Discontinuities often occur at piecewise boundaries.

title: Removable vs. Jump Discontinuity
content: A removable discontinuity occurs when a point can be redefined to make the function continuous. A jump discontinuity has a gap in the graph.

title: End Behavior Using Limits (Informal)
content: End behavior describes how f(x) behaves as x → ±∞. Analyze using algebraic structure or graph.

title: Nested Function Composition
content: When evaluating (f ∘ g)(x) for nested functions, start with the innermost expression and work outward step by step.

title: Modeling Real-World Contexts with Functions
content: Select appropriate functions to model linear, quadratic, exponential, or periodic real-world behavior.

title: Interval Notation and Set Builder Notation
content: Use interval notation to represent continuous domains or ranges (e.g., (a, b], [0, ∞)). Use set-builder notation to specify constraints (e.g., {x | x > 2}).

title: Vertical and Horizontal Stretch/Compression
content: Multiplying a function by a constant a > 1 stretches it vertically; 0 < a < 1 compresses it. Replacing x with bx stretches/compresses horizontally.

title: Even-Odd Composition Rule
content: If f is even and g is odd, then (f ∘ g)(x) is even. If both are odd, (f ∘ g)(x) is odd. Composition can change symmetry.

title: Parametric Representation of Functions
content: A parametric equation defines both x and y as functions of a third variable t, useful for describing motion and curves that aren’t functions in x.

title: Definition of Trigonometric Ratios
content: In a right triangle, sine is opposite/hypotenuse, cosine is adjacent/hypotenuse, and tangent is opposite/adjacent.

title: Reciprocal Trigonometric Ratios
content: Cosecant is the reciprocal of sine, secant is the reciprocal of cosine, and cotangent is the reciprocal of tangent.

title: Trigonometric Ratios on the Unit Circle
content: On the unit circle, for an angle θ in standard position, cos(θ) is the x-coordinate and sin(θ) is the y-coordinate of the point on the circle.

title: Radian Measure
content: A radian is the measure of a central angle that subtends an arc equal in length to the radius of the circle. 180° = π radians.

title: Converting Between Degrees and Radians
content: To convert degrees to radians, multiply by π/180. To convert radians to degrees, multiply by 180/π.

title: Coterminal Angles
content: Coterminal angles have the same terminal side and differ by a multiple of 2π (or 360°).

title: Reference Angle
content: A reference angle is the acute angle formed between the terminal side of an angle and the x-axis. It helps evaluate trig functions in all quadrants.

title: Signs of Trigonometric Functions by Quadrant
content: In Quadrant I: all positive, II: sin positive, III: tan positive, IV: cos positive. Remember using 'All Students Take Calculus'.

title: Evaluating Trig Functions of Special Angles
content: Know exact values of sine, cosine, and tangent for 0°, 30°, 45°, 60°, and 90°, and corresponding radian measures.

title: Circular (Real Number) Definition of Trig Functions
content: For any real number t, the coordinates of the point on the unit circle at arc length t define sin(t) = y and cos(t) = x. Other trig functions follow from ratios.

title: Graph of Sine Function
content: The graph of y = sin(x) is a smooth, periodic wave with amplitude 1, period 2π, and midline y = 0.

title: Graph of Cosine Function
content: The graph of y = cos(x) is a periodic wave identical in shape to sine, but starts at a maximum. It has amplitude 1 and period 2π.

title: Graph of Tangent Function
content: The graph of y = tan(x) has vertical asymptotes at x = ±π/2, ±3π/2, etc. It is periodic with period π and passes through the origin.

title: Amplitude of Trigonometric Functions
content: In y = a·sin(x) or y = a·cos(x), the amplitude is |a|, representing the vertical stretch from the midline.

title: Period of Sine and Cosine Functions
content: In y = sin(bx) or y = cos(bx), the period is 2π / |b|. Larger b results in more cycles over the same interval.

title: Phase Shift and Vertical Shift
content: In y = a·sin(b(x − c)) + d, c represents horizontal (phase) shift and d represents vertical shift (midline y = d).

title: Graphing a Transformed Sine or Cosine Function
content: To graph y = a·sin(b(x − c)) + d, determine amplitude, period, phase shift, and midline. Plot key points accordingly.

title: Graph of Secant and Cosecant Functions
content: Th graphs of y = sec(x) and y = csc(x) are based on reciprocals of cosine and sine. They have vertical asymptotes and form parabolic curves.

title: Graph of Cotangent Function
content: The graph of y = cot(x) has vertical asymptotes where sine is zero and period π. It decreases from left to right.

title: Modeling Periodic Behavior with Trig Functions
content: Trigonometric functions are used to model periodic phenomena such as sound waves, tides, or seasonal temperatures.

title: 5-Point Summary for Sinusoidal Graphs
content: To graph a sine or cosine function of the form y = a·sin(b(x − c)) + d or y = a·cos(b(x − c)) + d, identify: (1) Amplitude = |a|, (2) Period = 2π / |b|, (3) Phase Shift = c, (4) Vertical Shift = d (midline y = d), (5) Key Points: Start, Max, Mid, Min, End of one cycle.

title: Definition of Inverse Trigonometric Functions
content: The inverse trig functions undo sine, cosine, and tangent: arcsin, arccos, arctan. They return angles as outputs.

title: Domains and Ranges of Inverse Trig Functions
content: To be functions, inverse trig functions are defined on restricted domains: arcsin and arccos on [−1, 1], arctan on all real numbers.

title: Graphs of Inverse Trig Functions
content: The graph of arcsin(x) is a reflection of y = sin(x) over y = x on the restricted domain [−π/2, π/2]. Similar for arccos and arctan.

title: Solving Equations with Inverse Trig Functions
content: To solve equations like sin(θ) = x, use θ = arcsin(x). Consider general solutions or principal values based on context.

title: Compositions of Trig and Inverse Trig Functions
content: For example, sin(arcsin(x)) = x for x in [−1, 1], but arcsin(sin(x)) = x only when x is in [−π/2, π/2].

title: All Six Trig Functions on the Unit Circle
content: On the unit circle, define sin(θ) = y, cos(θ) = x, tan(θ) = y/x, csc(θ) = 1/y, sec(θ) = 1/x, and cot(θ) = x/y, where defined.

title: Inverse Secant, Cosecant, and Cotangent
content: The inverse secant, cosecant, and cotangent functions are less commonly used but defined with restricted ranges to be functions.

title: Summary of Inverse Trig Domains and Ranges
content: Create a table comparing domain and range of arcsin, arccos, arctan, arcsec, arccsc, arccot for quick reference.

title: Evaluating Inverse Trig of Special Values
content: Know values such as arcsin(1/2) = π/6, arccos(0) = π/2, and arctan(1) = π/4 for solving equations without a calculator.

title: Angle of Elevation and Depression Problems
content: Use right triangle trig and inverse functions to solve problems involving height, distance, and angle of elevation/depression.

title: Reciprocal Identities
content: csc(θ) = 1/sin(θ), sec(θ) = 1/cos(θ), cot(θ) = 1/tan(θ)

title: Quotient Identities
content: tan(θ) = sin(θ)/cos(θ), cot(θ) = cos(θ)/sin(θ)

title: Pythagorean Identities
content: sin²(θ) + cos²(θ) = 1, 1 + tan²(θ) = sec²(θ), 1 + cot²(θ) = csc²(θ)

title: Even-Odd Identities
content: sin(−θ) = −sin(θ), cos(−θ) = cos(θ), tan(−θ) = −tan(θ), etc. Used to simplify expressions involving negative angles.

title: Cofunction Identities
content: sin(π/2 − θ) = cos(θ), tan(π/2 − θ) = cot(θ), sec(π/2 − θ) = csc(θ), etc.

title: Verifying Trigonometric Identities
content: To verify identities, manipulate one side using known identities until it matches the other side. Use algebraic techniques like factoring or multiplying by conjugates.

title: Sum and Difference Identities
content: sin(A ± B) = sin A cos B ± cos A sin B, cos(A ± B) = cos A cos B ∓ sin A sin B, tan(A ± B) = (tan A ± tan B)/(1 ∓ tan A tan B)

title: Double-Angle Identities
content: sin(2θ) = 2 sin θ cos θ, cos(2θ) = cos²θ − sin²θ (or 2cos²θ − 1, 1 − 2sin²θ), tan(2θ) = 2tan θ / (1 − tan²θ)

title: Half-Angle Identities
content: sin²(θ/2) = (1 − cos θ)/2, cos²(θ/2) = (1 + cos θ)/2, tan(θ/2) = (1 − cos θ)/sin θ or sin θ / (1 + cos θ)

title: Product-to-Sum and Sum-to-Product Formulas
content: Convert products into sums and vice versa using identities such as sin A sin B = ½[cos(A−B) − cos(A+B)].

title: Solving Basic Trigonometric Equations
content: To solve equations like sin x = 1/2, find all angles with that value in the given domain using reference angles and unit circle knowledge.

title: General Solutions for Trigonometric Equations
content: Express all solutions using angle + period·n form, e.g., x = π/6 + 2πn and x = 5π/6 + 2πn for sin x = 1/2.

title: Using Identities to Solve Trig Equations
content: Rewrite trig equations using identities (e.g., Pythagorean, double-angle) to reduce to a single function.

title: Quadratic Form Trig Equations
content: Solve equations like 2sin²x − sin x − 1 = 0 by factoring or using the quadratic formula, then solving each resulting basic trig equation.

title: Using Substitution in Trig Equations
content: Let u = sin x or cos x to reduce complex equations into algebraic ones. Solve and back-substitute to find x.

title: Solving Trig Equations with Multiple Angles
content: When solving sin(2x) = 0 or similar, treat 2x as the new angle, solve for it, then divide to get x and write all valid solutions.

title: Using Graphs to Solve Trig Equations
content: Graph both sides of the equation and identify points of intersection. Useful for equations with transformations or multiple terms.

title: Solving Inequalities Involving Trig Functions
content: To solve inequalities like sin x > 1/2, first solve the related equation, then use interval analysis on the unit circle.

title: Extraneous Solutions in Trig Equations
content: Check all solutions in the original equation, especially after squaring or using identities. Some steps may introduce invalid results.

title: Law of Sines
content: In any triangle, the ratio of the length of a side to the sine of its opposite angle is constant: a/sin A = b/sin B = c/sin C.

title: Ambiguous Case for Law of Sines (SSA)
content: When given two sides and a non-included angle (SSA), there may be 0, 1, or 2 triangles depending on the height and angle configuration.

title: Law of Cosines
content: For any triangle: c² = a² + b² − 2ab·cos C. Useful when two sides and included angle or all three sides are known.

title: Choosing Between Laws of Sines and Cosines
content: Use Law of Sines when an angle-side pair is known (ASA, AAS, SSA). Use Law of Cosines for SAS and SSS configurations.

title: Area of Triangle Using Trigonometry
content: Area = (1/2)ab·sin C, where a and b are two sides and C is the included angle.

title: Heron’s Formula
content: If a triangle has side lengths a, b, c, and semi-perimeter s = (a + b + c)/2, then Area = √[s(s−a)(s−b)(s−c)].

title: Solving Triangles (Mixed Strategy)
content: To solve a triangle, choose Law of Sines or Cosines based on the given information. Compute unknown sides and angles step by step.

title: Trigonometric Form of Area and Ambiguity
content: Using the sine formula for area requires an included angle. In SSA cases, ensure the triangle is valid before applying.

title: Triple-Angle Identity for Sine and Cosine
content: sin(3θ) = 3sinθ − 4sin³θ, cos(3θ) = 4cos³θ − 3cosθ. These are used in advanced simplifications and triangle constructions.

title: Proof of Triple-Angle Identities
content: Triple-angle identities can be derived by applying sum identities to sin(2θ + θ) and cos(2θ + θ) and simplifying.

title: Definition of Complex Numbers
content: A complex number is of the form a + bi, where a and b are real numbers, and i is the imaginary unit defined by i² = −1.

title: Operations on Complex Numbers
content: To add or subtract, combine like terms. To multiply, use distributive property and simplify using i² = −1. To divide, multiply by the conjugate of the denominator.

title: Complex Conjugate
content: The complex conjugate of a + bi is a − bi. Multiplying a complex number by its conjugate yields a real number: (a + bi)(a − bi) = a² + b².

title: Absolute Value (Modulus) of a Complex Number
content: The absolute value of a + bi is √(a² + b²). It represents the distance from the origin in the complex plane.

title: Complex Plane and Graphing
content: The complex number a + bi can be graphed as the point (a, b) in the complex plane, with the x-axis as the real part and y-axis as the imaginary part.

title: Polar Form of Complex Numbers
content: A complex number can be written in polar form as r(cos θ + i sin θ), where r = |z| and θ is the argument (angle) of the complex number.

title: Converting Between Rectangular and Polar Form
content: To convert a + bi to polar, find r = √(a² + b²) and θ = arctan(b/a). To convert polar to rectangular, compute x = r cos θ, y = r sin θ.

title: Multiplying and Dividing in Polar Form
content: To multiply: multiply moduli and add angles. To divide: divide moduli and subtract angles.

title: De Moivre’s Theorem
content: If z = r(cos θ + i sin θ), then zⁿ = rⁿ[cos(nθ) + i sin(nθ)]. This is used to raise complex numbers to powers.

title: Finding Roots of Complex Numbers
content: To find the nth roots of a complex number, use the formula: r^(1/n)[cos((θ + 2kπ)/n) + i sin((θ + 2kπ)/n)] for k = 0, 1, ..., n−1.

title: Definition of a Matrix
content: A matrix is a rectangular array of numbers arranged in rows and columns. The size of a matrix is given as rows × columns (e.g., 3×3).

title: Matrix Addition and Scalar Multiplication
content: To add matrices, add corresponding entries. Scalar multiplication multiplies each entry of a matrix by a constant.

title: Matrix Multiplication
content: The product of an m×n matrix and an n×p matrix is an m×p matrix. Each entry is the dot product of row and column vectors.

title: Identity Matrix and Multiplicative Identity
content: The identity matrix I has 1s on the diagonal and 0s elsewhere. For a square matrix A, AI = IA = A.

title: Inverse of a 2×2 Matrix
content: For A = [[a, b], [c, d]], the inverse is (1/det A)·[[d, −b], [−c, a]] if det A ≠ 0.

title: Determinant of a 2×2 and 3×3 Matrix
content: For 2×2: det = ad − bc. For 3×3, use cofactor expansion or Sarrus’s Rule: det = aei + bfg + cdh − afh − bdi − ceg.

title: Inverse of a 3×3 Matrix (Conceptual)
content: To find the inverse of a 3×3 matrix, use the adjugate and determinant: A⁻¹ = (1/det A)·adj(A), if det A ≠ 0.

title: Solving Systems with Matrices (2×2 or 3×3)
content: Write the system as AX = B, then solve using X = A⁻¹B if A is invertible.

title: Row Reduction and Echelon Form
content: Use Gaussian or Gauss-Jordan elimination to solve systems by converting the augmented matrix to row echelon or reduced row echelon form.

title: Applications of Matrices
content: Matrices can model systems in economics, networks, cryptography, and computer graphics transformations.

title: Intuitive Definition of a Limit
content: The limit of f(x) as x approaches a is the value f(x) gets closer to as x gets closer to a. Notation: limₓ→ₐ f(x).

title: One-Sided Limits
content: The left-hand limit is limₓ→ₐ⁻ f(x), and the right-hand limit is limₓ→ₐ⁺ f(x). A limit exists at a if both one-sided limits are equal.

title: Limits from a Table or Graph
content: To estimate a limit numerically, observe the trend of values as x approaches a. Graphically, examine the y-values approaching a point.

title: Limits Involving Infinity
content: If f(x) increases or decreases without bound as x approaches a value, write limₓ→ₐ f(x) = ∞ or −∞. The limit does not exist in the finite sense.

title: Limit Does Not Exist (DNE)
content: A limit fails to exist when the left- and right-hand limits are unequal, the function oscillates, or it diverges to infinity.

title: Infinite Limits at Infinity
content: As x → ∞ or x → −∞, examine the end behavior of f(x). Limits can approach a finite number or diverge to ∞.

title: Limits and Asymptotic Behavior
content: Vertical asymptotes occur where the function grows without bound. Horizontal asymptotes reflect the limit as x → ∞ or −∞.

title: Algebraic Limit Evaluation
content: Use substitution first. If undefined, try factoring, rationalizing, or using conjugates to simplify and then re-evaluate the limit.

title: Piecewise Function Limits
content: For piecewise-defined functions, evaluate left-hand and right-hand limits using appropriate pieces. Check for discontinuities at transition points.

title: Definition of Continuity at a Point
content: A function is continuous at x = a if limₓ→ₐ f(x) exists, f(a) exists, and limₓ→ₐ f(x) = f(a).

title: Algebraic Manipulation or Simplification
content: Algebraic expressions can be simplified or manipulated by applying arithmetic rules, exponent rules, or factoring techniques, as long as logical equivalence is maintained.
